userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 廣間
userdata.description:
廣間 / ひろま： 進入日式宿舍的位置，稱為「玄關」。「玄關」是主要出入口，日本人有脫鞋進屋的習慣，因此玄關為脫鞋及擺放鞋子、外出用具的地方。
玄關由兩個部分組成：一是進入室內脫鞋的部分，通常是以水泥地面的舖設為主，稱為「土間」或「踏入」；二是進入主要居室空間之前，地板抬高舖有木地板的部分，稱為「廣間」，主要做為迎客送客的地方。

hotspot.title: 入室規定
hotspot.description: 脫鞋穿襪入內 寵物禁止入內

hotspot.title: 室內襪販賣
hotspot.description: 為保護古蹟建物，入內請脫鞋著襪，如需添購襪子請在此挑選，穿完的襪子請丟入旁邊的盒子。

userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 應接室
userdata.description:
応接室 / おうせつしつ ： 應接室是日式住宅受到近代西方文化影響後，而出現的空間。
由於當時較少酒吧或咖啡廳等公共場所，因此中上流階級住家或是官階較高的宿舍會於室內設置應接室以招待賓客，平入可兼讀書寫字的書齋。
其天花板高度高於室內其他空間，突顯此處是主要空間同時也彰顯賓客地位。不同於傳統之會客場所的席地而坐，應接室通常備有座椅，因此地坪以木地板取代傳統榻榻米。

userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 書齋
userdata.description:
書斎 / しょさい ： 日式建築中的「書齋」是指一個供讀書寫字的房間，通常布置得簡潔舒適，有著高度的私密性和專注性，旨在提供一個專門的空間，供人沉澱思考、閱讀寫作和學習。
在傳統的日式建築中，書齋通常位於房屋內部，靠近園林或庭院，以便可以欣賞到美景，同時避免了外界的喧嘩干擾。房間的裝飾簡約，牆壁、天花板和地板都使用天然材料，如木材、竹子和稻草等。房間內通常配有書桌、書架、墨水硯臺等學習寫作工具，以及茶具、花器等生活用品，以增強房間的舒適感和實用性。
書齋在日本傳統文化中有著重要的地位，它不僅是學習和寫作的場所，也是傳統文人雅士重視的文化象徵之一。

hotspot.title: 懷舊飾品 請勿動手操作
hotspot.description: 無功能擺飾，僅供觀賞，請勿操作以免造成損壞。

hotspot.title: 大日本帝國台灣地形地質礦產地圖

userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 緣側
userdata.description:
緣側 / えんがわ： 它在日語的意思為「屋檐下的架空廊」，指的是設計在房子外圍的走廊，是住宅內通往後院的中介空間，也是各居室間的聯絡通道，大多為朝向中庭的位置。 這樣的區塊讓人們可以隨意席地而坐喝一杯，也能是談笑小憩的愜意空間，日夜晴雨都充滿不同的魅力。
作為傳統房屋中的外廊部分，為過渡室內與室外的中介空間，可以作為連接屋內外到庭園間的過道，可做為因應防颱、防風、防雨而設置雨戶（擋雨的實木板）。

userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 居間
userdata.description:
居間 / いま： 顧名思義是「在的地方」。在日本古時指的是「主人在的地方」，現在多半被翻譯為Living Room(客廳)，但是在當時空間的使用上，應該比較接近現在的臥室。這個和生活方式的不同有關。也就是當時的生活並沒有區分臥室和客廳。臥室通常就是待一整天的地方。
在日本傳統文化中，居間是一個家庭成員和客人交流和休息的重要場所。在這裡，人們可以一起食用飯菜、觀賞電視、聊天、玩樂器等，這些活動都可以增進家庭成員和朋友之間的感情。

userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 座敷
userdata.description:
座敷 / ざしき： 是指日本傳統建築中的一種房間，通常用於接待客人、舉行茶會等社交活動。在日本古典文學中，「座敷」也經常被提及，例如《源氏物語》中的「紅葉賞」、《枕草子》中的「枕草子之段」等，都是描寫座敷裡的生活和文化風貌。
座敷的特點是房間內部分為略高的榻榻米地面，周圍用簾子圍起來，通常還會在榻榻米上鋪上蒲團等坐墊。座敷一般都裝飾得非常精美，擺放著花鳥畫、屏風、蕾絲簾等，讓人感受到優雅的氛圍。
在傳統的日本社交文化中，座敷被視為一個重要的場所，通常是招待賓客、朋友或家族成員的地方，也是交流情感和文化的場所。在座敷中，人們會喝茶、品嚐點心，互相交談，感受著雅致的環境和文化氛圍。因此，座敷在日本的傳統文化中扮演了重要的角色。

userdata.author: James Lee
userdata.title: 次之間
userdata.description:
次之間 / つぎのま： 與「座敷」相鄰空間為「次間」，原是「座敷」的備用空間，當有重要活動時，移除隔間的「襖」，就跟「座敷」形成一個容納多人的大空間。平日通常做為居室空間，原本設有兩個儲放寢具的「押入」，但現在左右兩戶的「次間」被打通成一大間，「押入」也都被拆除了。
「次之間」是日本傳統建築中的一種房間，通常用於連接不同功能的房間或者是作為走廊使用。它通常位於主要房間和其他房間之間，並且在結構和裝飾上都比較簡單，不像座敷一樣華麗。
在日本的傳統建築中，「次之間」扮演著重要的角色，因為它連接了不同房間，使整個建築結構更加有機地連接在一起，同時也為人們提供了一個可以休息、放置物品和移動的場所。
「次之間」和起居間在日本傳統建築中是不同的概念，它們的功能和用途也不完全相同。
起居間是日本傳統建築中一個比較大的房間，通常用於家庭生活和活動，如吃飯、睡覺、看電視等。起居間通常裝飾華麗，擺放家具和蒲團等坐墊，人們可以在這裡舒適地休息和交流。起居間通常是一個家庭的主要活動區域。
相比之下，「次之間」的功能更加簡單，主要是連接不同的房間或者作為走廊使用。它的大小和裝飾比起居間更加簡單，通常只放置一些簡單的傢俱和裝飾物品。總的來說，「次之間」和起居間的功能和用途是不同的，它們各自在日本傳統建築中扮演著不同的角色。
花蓮縣縣定古蹟「檢察長宿舍」古蹟活化
userdata.title: 斗宅。揀茶舍

顧名思義是「在的地方」。在日本古時指的是「主人在的地方」，現在多半被翻譯為Living Room(客廳)，但是在當時空間的使用上，應該比較接近現在的臥室。這個和生活方式的不同有關。也就是當時的生活並沒有區分臥室和客廳。臥室通常就是待一整天的地方。

在日本傳統文化中，居間是一個家庭成員和客人交流和休息的重要場所。在這裡，人們可以一起食用飯菜、觀賞電視、聊天、玩樂器等，這些活動都可以增進家庭成員和朋友之間的感情。":["Ima (いま) :
Literally meaning "the place where one is," the term ima in traditional Japan originally referred to "the place where the head of the household stays." Today, it is often translated as "living room," but in terms of spatial use at that time, it was closer to what we now consider a bedroom. This difference is related to lifestyle changes, as traditional Japanese living did not clearly distinguish between bedroom and living room. The bedroom was typically the place where one spent the entire day.

In traditional Japanese culture, the ima was an important space for family members and guests to communicate and relax. It was a place where people could share meals, watch television, chat, play musical instruments, and engage in other activities that fostered closeness among family and friends."],"居間前走道":["Aisle beside Ima"],"左便所走道":["Corridor beside the left restroom"],"左外座位區":["Left outer seating area"],"左外走道":["left outer aisle"],"座敷":["Zashiki (ざしき)"],"座敷 / ざしき：
是指日本傳統建築中的一種房間，通常用於接待客人、舉行茶會等社交活動。在日本古典文學中，「座敷」也經常被提及，例如《源氏物語》中的「紅葉賞」、《枕草子》中的「枕草子之段」等，都是描寫座敷裡的生活和文化風貌。

座敷的特點是房間內部分為略高的榻榻米地面，周圍用簾子圍起來，通常還會在榻榻米上鋪上蒲團等坐墊。座敷一般都裝飾得非常精美，擺放著花鳥畫、屏風、蕾絲簾等，讓人感受到優雅的氛圍。

在傳統的日本社交文化中，座敷被視為一個重要的場所，通常是招待賓客、朋友或家族成員的地方，也是交流情感和文化的場所。在座敷中，人們會喝茶、品嚐點心，互相交談，感受著雅致的環境和文化氛圍。因此，座敷在日本的傳統文化中扮演了重要的角色。":["Zashiki (ざしき) :
A zashiki refers to a type of room in traditional Japanese architecture, typically used for receiving guests, hosting tea ceremonies, and other social activities. In classical Japanese literature, zashiki is frequently mentioned—for example, in The Tale of Genji during the "Maple Viewing" chapter, and in The Pillow Book—depicting the lifestyle and cultural ambiance within such rooms.

The distinctive feature of a zashiki is its slightly elevated tatami flooring area, often enclosed by curtains. Tatami mats are typically covered with cushions called zabuton or futon for seating. The room is usually decorated elegantly with elements such as bird-and-flower paintings, folding screens (byōbu), and lace curtains, creating a refined atmosphere.

In traditional Japanese social culture, the zashiki is considered an important space for entertaining guests, friends, and family members. It serves as a place for emotional and cultural exchange. Within the zashiki, people enjoy tea, sweets, and conversations while appreciating the elegant environment and cultural ambience. Therefore, the zashiki holds a significant role in Japan’s traditional cultural heritage."],"廣間":["Hiroma"],"廣間 / ひろま：
進入日式宿舍的位置，稱為「玄關」。「玄關」是主要出入口，日本人有脫鞋進屋的習慣，因此玄關為脫鞋及擺放鞋子、外出用具的地方。

玄關由兩個部分組成：一是進入室內脫鞋的部分，通常是以水泥地面的舖設為主，稱為「土間」或「踏入」；二是進入主要居室空間之前，地板抬高舖有木地板的部分，稱為「廣間」，主要做為迎客送客的地方。":["Hiroma/Hiroba:
The place where you enter a Japanese dormitory is called the “Genkan ( traditional Japanese entryway)”. The “Genkan” is the main entrance and exit, Japanese people have the habit of taking off their shoes to enter the house, so the entrance is the place to take off shoes and put shoes and go out utensils.

The genkan is composed of two main parts:
The first is the area where one steps into the interior and removes their shoes. This section typically features a concrete floor and is referred to as the "doma" or "step-in area."
The second part, located before entering the main living space, is a raised wooden floor area called the "hiroma." This space serves primarily as a place to greet and bid farewell to guests."],"後院":["Backyard"],"応接室 / おうせつしつ ：
應接室是日式住宅受到近代西方文化影響後，而出現的空間。

由於當時較少酒吧或咖啡廳等公共場所，因此中上流階級住家或是官階較高的宿舍會於室內設置應接室以招待賓客，平入可兼讀書寫字的書齋。

其天花板高度高於室內其他空間，突顯此處是主要空間同時也彰顯賓客地位。不同於傳統之會客場所的席地而坐，應接室通常備有座椅，因此地坪以木地板取代傳統榻榻米。":["Ōsetsu-shitsu (Reception Room)：
The ōsetsu-shitsu is a reception room that emerged in Japanese residences under the influence of Western culture during the modern era.

At a time when public venues such as cafés or bars were scarce, middle- and upper-class homes, as well as official residences of high-ranking officials, began incorporating reception rooms within the home to receive guests. These rooms also often served as private studies for reading and writing.

The ceiling of the reception room was typically higher than that of other interior spaces, emphasizing its importance and symbolizing the elevated status of the guests. Unlike traditional Japanese guest rooms where people sat on tatami mats, reception rooms were furnished with chairs and featured wooden flooring instead of tatami, reflecting Western architectural influence."],"應接室":["Reception Room"],"懷舊飾品 請勿動手操作":["Nostalgic Items — Please Do Not Handle"],"戶外取餐區":["Picking Up Area"],"斗宅。揀茶舍":["Shiba Inu Café Roasters"],"書斎 / しょさい ：
日式建築中的「書齋」是指一個供讀書寫字的房間，通常布置得簡潔舒適，有著高度的私密性和專注性，旨在提供一個專門的空間，供人沉澱思考、閱讀寫作和學習。

在傳統的日式建築中，書齋通常位於房屋內部，靠近園林或庭院，以便可以欣賞到美景，同時避免了外界的喧嘩干擾。房間的裝飾簡約，牆壁、天花板和地板都使用天然材料，如木材、竹子和稻草等。房間內通常配有書桌、書架、墨水硯臺等學習寫作工具，以及茶具、花器等生活用品，以增強房間的舒適感和實用性。

書齋在日本傳統文化中有著重要的地位，它不僅是學習和寫作的場所，也是傳統文人雅士重視的文化象徵之一。":["Study (書斎 / しょさい / Shosai):
In traditional Japanese architecture, the shosai refers to a room designated for reading, writing, and study. It is typically furnished in a simple and comfortable manner, emphasizing privacy and focus. The purpose of the room is to offer a dedicated, tranquil space for reflection, learning, and literary work.

In a traditional Japanese house, the study is usually located in an interior part of the building, often adjacent to a garden or courtyard. This placement allows the occupant to enjoy a scenic view while being shielded from external noise and distractions. The room features minimalist decor, with natural materials used for the walls, ceiling, and flooring—such as wood, bamboo, and straw. Inside, it is commonly equipped with essential items like a writing desk, bookshelves, inkstone and brush for calligraphy, as well as daily-use items like a tea set or flower vase, enhancing both its comfort and functionality.

The study holds a significant place in traditional Japanese culture. It is not only a space for intellectual pursuits but also a cultural symbol valued by scholars and literati as a reflection of refinement and introspection."],"書齋":["Study Room"],"月亮燈座位區（夜）":["Moon Lantern Seating Area（Japanese Style） - Night"],"月亮燈座位區（日）":["Moon Lantern Seating Area（Japanese Style） - Day"],"次之間":["Tsuqima 次の間 （つぎのま）："],"次之間 / つぎのま：
與「座敷」相鄰空間為「次間」，原是「座敷」的備用空間，當有重要活動時，移除隔間的「襖」，就跟「座敷」形成一個容納多人的大空間。平日通常做為居室空間，原本設有兩個儲放寢具的「押入」，但現在左右兩戶的「次間」被打通成一大間，「押入」也都被拆除了。

「次之間」是日本傳統建築中的一種房間，通常用於連接不同功能的房間或者是作為走廊使用。它通常位於主要房間和其他房間之間，並且在結構和裝飾上都比較簡單，不像座敷一樣華麗。

在日本的傳統建築中，「次之間」扮演著重要的角色，因為它連接了不同房間，使整個建築結構更加有機地連接在一起，同時也為人們提供了一個可以休息、放置物品和移動的場所。


「次之間」和起居間在日本傳統建築中是不同的概念，它們的功能和用途也不完全相同。

起居間是日本傳統建築中一個比較大的房間，通常用於家庭生活和活動，如吃飯、睡覺、看電視等。起居間通常裝飾華麗，擺放家具和蒲團等坐墊，人們可以在這裡舒適地休息和交流。起居間通常是一個家庭的主要活動區域。

相比之下，「次之間」的功能更加簡單，主要是連接不同的房間或者作為走廊使用。它的大小和裝飾比起居間更加簡單，通常只放置一些簡單的傢俱和裝飾物品。總的來說，「次之間」和起居間的功能和用途是不同的，它們各自在日本傳統建築中扮演著不同的角色。":["Tsuqima 次の間 （つぎのま）：
The tsugima is an adjacent room to the zashiki in traditional Japanese architecture. Originally, it served as a backup space for the zashiki. During important occasions, the sliding partitions (fusuma) between the tsugima and zashiki could be removed to create a large open space accommodating many people. On regular days, it functioned as a living room with two built-in closets (oshiire) for bedding storage. However, in some cases, the tsugima rooms of neighboring houses have been combined into a larger space, and the closets have been removed.

The tsugima is a type of room typically used to connect rooms of different functions or serve as a corridor. It is usually located between the main room and other rooms, with simpler structural design and decoration compared to the more ornate zashiki.

In traditional Japanese architecture, the tsugima plays an important role by linking various rooms, creating an organically connected overall layout. It also provides a place for resting, storage, and passage.

It is important to distinguish tsugima from the ima (living room). The ima is a larger, more elaborately decorated room used for family living activities such as dining, sleeping, and entertainment. It typically contains furniture and cushions (zabuton), offering a comfortable space for rest and social interaction. In contrast, the tsugima has simpler functions—primarily as a connector or corridor—with minimal decoration and fewer furnishings. Both rooms serve different roles in traditional Japanese residential design."],"為保護古蹟建物，入內請脫鞋著襪，如需添購襪子請在此挑選，穿完的襪子請丟入旁邊的盒子。":["To help preserve the historic building, please remove your shoes and wear socks before entering.
If you need an extra pair of socks, feel free to select one here.
After use, kindly place the used socks into the box provided."],"無功能擺飾，僅供觀賞，請勿操作以免造成損壞。":["Non-functional decoration for viewing only. Please do not handle to avoid damage."],"緣側":["Engawa (えんがわ)"],"緣側 / えんがわ：
它在日語的意思為「屋檐下的架空廊」，指的是設計在房子外圍的走廊，是住宅內通往後院的中介空間，也是各居室間的聯絡通道，大多為朝向中庭的位置。 這樣的區塊讓人們可以隨意席地而坐喝一杯，也能是談笑小憩的愜意空間，日夜晴雨都充滿不同的魅力。

作為傳統房屋中的外廊部分，為過渡室內與室外的中介空間，可以作為連接屋內外到庭園間的過道，可做為因應防颱、防風、防雨而設置雨戶（擋雨的實木板）。
":["Engawa (えんがわ):
In Japanese, "engawa" refers to a "raised veranda under the eaves" — a corridor designed around the exterior of a house. It serves as an intermediary space leading from the interior of the residence to the backyard and also acts as a passageway connecting various rooms, usually facing the central courtyard. This area allows people to casually sit on the floor to enjoy a drink or relax in a pleasant space for chatting and leisure. It holds a unique charm throughout day and night, in both sunny and rainy weather.

As the outer corridor in traditional houses, the engawa functions as a transitional space between indoors and outdoors. It acts as a pathway connecting the interior of the house to the garden outside. Additionally, it can be equipped with "amado" — storm shutters made of solid wood, designed to protect against typhoons, strong winds, and rain.
"],"脫鞋穿襪入內
寵物禁止入內":["Please remove your shoes and wear socks before entering.
No pets allowed inside."],"花蓮縣縣定古蹟「檢察長宿舍」古蹟活化":["Historic Preservation and Revitalization of the Prosecutor-General’s Residence, a Hualien County Designated Monument."],"踏入外入口":["Outer entry doma"]}}
